title: CBC Radio
text:
If you can remember the classic story of Don Quixote, you'll know that the tale tells the story of an ageing knight that sets off on a quest to find the love of his life.

In Salman Rushdie's latest novel, Quichotte, the author re-frames the classic story of Don Quixote to examine the tug-of-war between fact and fiction in our current world and the devastation of addiction.

The esteemed author is considered one of the greatest novelist living today. He wrote Midnight's Children, The Satanic Verses and The Golden House. He's the recipient of the Booker Prize and many other awards.

Talking to q host Tom Power, Rushdie explores the impact of reality television on our lives and explains why he felt he needed to write about the opioid crisis in his latest book.

Rushdie explained to q host Tom Power, "That's the thing that a novel can do, it can remind us of the good. It can remind us that even at a time when we seem surrounded and overwhelmed by craziness and evil there is such a thing as the good and there are people, including ourselves, who strive for that."

Rushdie's new novel Quichotte is out on Saturday, September 7. You can catch him in conversation with Candy Palmater at the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto on Monday, September 30.

— Produced by ​Diane Eros

description: Salman Rushdie explains how his latest novel, Quichotte, re-frames the classic story of Don Quixote to examine the power of mass media and addiction in the present day world.
